(b)  No dealer shall purchase precious metals or gems from any seller who the dealer believes or has reason to believe is not the owner of such items, unless the seller has written and duly authenticated authorization from the owner permitting and directing such sale. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4103. 
Sec. 18-86. - Dealer to retain purchases. 
(a)  The dealer shall retain all precious metals or gems purchased for a minimum of ten calendar days from the date on which a copy of the bill of sale is received by the chief law enforcement officer of the locality in which the purchase is made. Until the expiration of this period, the dealer shall not sell, alter, or dispose of a purchased item in whole or in part, or remove it from the county, city, or town in which the purchase was made. 
(b)  If a dealer performs the service of removing precious metals or gems, he shall retain the metals or gems removed and the article from which the removal was made for a period of ten calendar days after receiving such article and precious metals or gems. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4104. 
Sec. 18-87. - Record of disposition. 
    Each dealer shall maintain for at least 24 months an accurate and legible record of the name and address of the person to whom he sells any precious metal or gem in its original form after the waiting period required by section 18-86. This record shall also show the name and address of the seller from whom the dealer purchased the item. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4105. 
Sec. 18-88. - Bond or letter of credit required of dealers when permit obtained. 
(a)  Every dealer shall secure a permit as required by section 18-90, and each dealer at the time of obtaining such permit shall enter into a recognizance to the commonwealth secured by a corporate surety authorized to do business in this commonwealth, in the penal sum of $10,000.00, conditioned upon due observance of the terms of this article. In lieu of a bond, a dealer may cause to be issued by a bank authorized to do business in the commonwealth a letter of credit in favor of the commonwealth for $10,000.00. 
(b)  A single bond upon an employer or principal may be written or a single letter of credit issued to cover all employees and all transactions occurring at a single location. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4106. 
Sec. 18-89. - Private action on bond or letter of credit. 
    Any person aggrieved by the misconduct of any dealer which violated the provisions of this article may maintain an action for recovery in any court of proper jurisdiction against the dealer and his surety. Recovery against the surety shall be only for that amount of the judgment which is unsatisfied by the dealer. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4107. 
Sec. 18-90. - Permit required; method of obtaining permit; no convictions of certain crimes; approval of weighing devices; renewal; permanent location required. 
(a)  No person shall engage in the activities of a dealer as defined in section 18-81 without first obtaining a permit from the chief law enforcement officer of each county, city, or town in which he proposes to engage in business. 
(b)  To obtain a permit, the dealer shall file with the proper chief law enforcement officer an application form which includes the dealer's full name, any aliases, address, age, date of birth, sex, and fingerprints; the name, address, and telephone number of the applicant's employer, if any; and the location of the dealer's place of business. Upon filing this application and the payment of an application fee of $200.00, the dealer shall be issued a permit by the chief law enforcement officer or his designee, provided that the applicant has not been convicted of a felony or crime of moral turpitude within seven years prior to the date of application. The permit shall be denied if the applicant has been denied a permit or has had a permit revoked under this article or any ordinance similar in substance to the provisions of this article. 
(c)  Before a permit may be issued, the dealer must have all weighing devices used in his business inspected and approved by local or state weights and measures officials and present written evidence of such approval to the proper chief law enforcement officer. 
(d)  This permit shall be valid for one year from the date issued and may be renewed in the same manner as such permit was initially obtained with an annual permit fee of $200.00. No permit shall be transferable. 
(e)  If the business of the dealer is not operated without interruption, with Saturdays, Sundays, and recognized holidays excepted, the dealer shall notify the proper chief law enforcement officer of all closings and reopenings of such business. The business of a dealer shall be conducted only from the fixed and permanent location specified in his application for a permit. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4108. 
Sec. 18-91. - Exemptions from article. 
(a)  The chief law enforcement officer of the city, or his designee, may waive by written notice implementation of any one or more of the provisions of this chapter, except section 18-85, for particular numismatic, gem, or antique exhibitions or craft shows sponsored by nonprofit organizations, provided that the purpose of the exhibitions is nonprofit in nature, notwithstanding the fact that there may be casual purchases and trades made at such exhibitions. 
(b)  This article shall not apply to the sale or purchase of coins. 
(c)  This article shall not apply to any bank, branch thereof, trust company or bank holding company, or any wholly owned subsidiary thereof, engaged in buying and selling gold and silver bullion. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4109. 
Sec. 18-92. - Penalties for violation of article; first and subsequent offenses. 
(a)  Any person convicted of violating any of the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a class 2 misdemeanor for the first offense. Upon conviction of any subsequent offense he shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(b)  Upon the first conviction of a dealer for violation of any provision of this article, the chief law enforcement officer may revoke the dealer's permit for one full year from the date the conviction becomes final. Such revocation shall be mandatory upon a second conviction. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4110. 
Secs. 18-93-18-115. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - MASSAGE ESTABLISHMENTS 

Sec. 18-116. - Prohibited acts; application of section. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person or any other entity responsible for the operation of any establishment, regardless whether it is a public or private facility, to operate as a massage salon, bath parlor, or any similar type business, where any physical contact with the recipient of such services is provided by a person of the opposite sex. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person, whether as an employee of a massage parlor, massage salon, bath parlor, an out-call massage service, or of any similar type business, or an individual, whether licensed under any section of this Code, to massage or rub the body of a person of the opposite sex. 
(c)  This section shall not apply to a physician, surgeon, chiropractor, osteopath, naturopath, physical therapist, or massage therapist duly licensed by the commonwealth, or to a licensed nurse acting under the direct prescription and direction of any such physician, surgeon, chiropractor, osteopath, or naturopath. Also, this section shall not apply to barbershops or beauty parlors in which massage is given to the scalp, the face, the neck or the shoulders. 
(Code 1972, § 14-225; Ord. No. 04-11, § 1, 3-16-04) 
Secs. 18-117-18-140. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - TATTOO PARLORS[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Sanitation in tattoo parlors, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-28.3. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 18-141. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Tattoo means to mark or color the skin by pricking in coloring matter so as to form indelible marks or figures or by the production of scars. 
    Tattoo artist means any person who actually performs the work of tattooing. 
    Tattoo operator means any person who controls, operates, conducts, or manages any tattoo establishment, whether actually performing the work of tattooing or not. 
    Tattoo parlor means any room or space where tattooing is practiced or where the business of tattooing is conducted or any part thereof. 
(Code 1972, § 14-400) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 18-142. - Penalty for violation of article. 
    Any person who shall conduct a tattoo parlor or engage in business as a tattoo operator or tattoo artist without first securing a permit therefor, or when such permit previously issued has been revoked or suspended, or who shall violate any of the other provisions of this article shall be guilty of a Class 4 misdemeanor. The director of public health shall revoke the permit of any person who shall be convicted once within a 24-month period of violating any of the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1972, § 14-409; Ord. No. 08-08, 3-18-08) 
Sec. 18-143. - Physical examinations of and health requirements for tattoo artists. 
    Each tattoo artist shall have an annual physical examination reported on a form to be prescribed by the department of public health, which physical examination shall include an X-ray of the chest and such other laboratory tests as may be deemed necessary by the department of public health. A report of the physical examination and laboratory tests shall be presented with the application for each permit for a tattoo parlor or for any renewal thereof. No persons shall engage in tattooing as a tattoo artist while in the communicable state of any disease, including the common cold. 
(Code 1972, § 14-404) 
Sec. 18-144. - Records required to be kept by operators. 
    Proper records for each patron or customer shall be kept and maintained by the tattoo operator of each tattoo parlor, which record shall include the patron or customer's name, address, date, and signature of patron or customer. All records shall be available for inspection upon request of department of public health. 
(Code 1972, § 14-405) 
Sec. 18-145. - Minors. 
    No tattoo operator or tattoo artist shall tattoo any person who is under the age of 18 unless such person shall present to the tattoo operator or artist notarized consent to such tattooing from a parent or guardian of such person. In this event, the notarized consent shall be attached to and become a part of the records referred to in section 18-44. 
(Code 1972, § 14-406; Ord. No. 08-08, 3-18-08) 
Sec. 18-146. - Prohibited designs, words or phrases. 
    No tattoo operator or tattoo artist shall tattoo on any person any obscene word, phrase, or design. 
(Code 1972, § 14-407) 
State Law reference- "Obscene" defined, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-372. 
Sec. 18-147. - Removal of tattoo. 
    No tattoo operator or artist shall remove or attempt to remove any tattoo. 
(Code 1972, § 14-408) 
Sec. 18-148. - Required facilities for parlors. 
    Each tattooing parlor shall have an operating room, which operating room shall be separate and apart from a waiting room or such other rooms as may be used. Patrons or customers shall be tattooed only in such operating room. The operating room shall be equipped with hot and cold running water, together with such sinks and basins as may be necessary. Sufficient toilet, urinal, and handwashing facilities shall be accessible to customers, operators, and artists within the tattoo parlor or the building in which the tattoo parlor is located. 
(Code 1972, § 14-410) 
Sec. 18-149. - Personal cleanliness of tattoo artist; required equipment. 
    There shall be available within the tattoo parlor adequate hot and cold running water, soap, approved germicidal solution, individual hand brushes and fingernail files for each tattoo artist. Each tattoo artist shall clean his fingernails with an individual file, wash his hands with soap and hot water, using an individual hand brush, and thoroughly rinse his hands in a germicidal solution to be approved by the department of public health before working on each patron or customer. An individual paper towel or napkin shall be used for drying the tattoo artists' hands after rinsing. Each tattoo artist shall wear sterile rubber gloves and a clean gown or coat while actually engaged in tattooing. 
(Code 1972, § 14-411) 
Sec. 18-150. - Cabinets for storage of equipment. 
    Adequate cabinets for the storage of instruments, dyes, carbon, and stencils shall be provided for each operator and shall be maintained in a sanitary condition. 
(Code 1972, § 14-412) 
Sec. 18-151. - Floors; disposition of waste material. 
    The floor of tattoo parlors shall be of impervious material and shall be at all times maintained in a clean condition. The tattoo parlor shall have proper facilities for the disposition of waste material. 
(Code 1972, § 14-413) 
Sec. 18-152. - Ventilation; walls and ceilings. 
    Tattoo parlors must have adequate light and ventilation, and all walls and ceilings shall be painted a light color. 
(Code 1972, § 14-414) 
Sec. 18-153. - Instructions as to care of skin after tattooing. 
    Printed or mimeographed instructions, approved by the director of public health, shall be given to each patron or customer on the care of the skin after tattooing as a precaution to prevent infection after each tattooing. A copy of these instructions shall also be posted in a conspicuous place in the tattoo parlor, clearly visible to the person being tattooed. 
(Code 1972, § 14-415) 
Sec. 18-154. - Preparation of area to be tattooed. 
    When it is necessary to shave the area to be tattooed, a new blade for each patron shall be used when a safety razor is employed, and the permanent parts of such safety razor shall be treated as set forth in this section for the treatment of a straight razor. If a straight razor is used, it shall be cleansed with soap and water, rinsed in clean water, and then sterilized by being immersed for 15 minutes in an approved germicidal solution, or by boiling for a period of at least five minutes before the razor is used again on another person. After shaving the area to be tattooed, such area shall be cleaned with an approved germicidal solution in a sanitary manner before the design is placed on the skin. 
(Code 1972, § 14-416) 
Sec. 18-155. - Stencil for transferring design. 
    The stencil for transferring the design to the skin shall be thoroughly cleaned and rinsed in an approved germicidal solution. 
(Code 1972, § 14-417) 
Sec. 18-156. - Removal of excess dye; bandages. 
    The excess dye originally applied to the skin shall be removed with individual sterile gauze or sterile cotton only. The area tattooed shall then be allowed to dry and the entire area covered with a piece of sterile gauze only, which may in turn be covered with a piece of tissue and fastened with adhesive. 
(Code 1972, § 14-418) 
Sec. 18-157. - Needles. 
    A sterile set of needles must be used for each patron or customer. Needles used in tattooing shall be sterilized by being placed in boiling water for a period of at least five minutes, shaken dry, and if not immediately used, stored in sterile containers. The open end of the needle tube of the tattooing machine shall be cleaned and sterilized in a similar manner before each use. 
(Code 1972, § 14-419) 
Sec. 18-158. - Sterilizing device required. 
    Each tattoo parlor shall be equipped with a sterilizing device to be approved by the director of public health. 
(Code 1972, § 14-420) 
Secs. 18-159-18-175. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 18-176. - Application; inspections. 
    No person shall operate a tattoo parlor, or engage in the practice or business of tattooing as a tattoo operator or as a tattoo artist, unless such person shall first secure a permit from the director of public health or his duly authorized assistant. Applications for any such permit shall be made in writing on a form prescribed by the director of public health, wherein the applicant shall agree to conform to all ordinances, rules, and regulations governing such places now in effect or as subsequently enacted, and to permit such examination and inspections as may be deemed necessary by the director of public health. Before such permit is granted, it shall be the duty of the health officer to cause an inspection to be made of the premises or tattoo parlor in which the business is to be conducted and to refuse the permit if the condition of the premises, its equipment, or the health of the applicant shall not conform to the requirements of this article, but if the same do conform to the requirements of this article, the director of public health shall issue the permit requested. It shall be the further duty of the health officer to cause inspections to be made from time to time of all tattoo parlors and the equipment thereof, and if the place of business is not maintained, conducted or operated in conformity with the requirements of this article, as now enacted or as subsequently amended, then the director of public health may suspend the permit of the operator or artist until the tattoo parlor and the operation thereof is made to conform to the requirements of this article. 
(Code 1972, § 14-401) 
Sec. 18-177. - Term; renewal. 
    All permits issued pursuant to this article shall, unless sooner revoked, expire on December 31 following their date of issue. Applications for the renewal of permits shall be made on or before December 1 following their date of issue and the requirements for the renewal thereof shall be the same as for new permits, as set 
(Code 1972, § 14-402; Ord. No. 08-08, 3-18-08) 
Sec. 18-178. - Form and transfer. 
    All permits granted shall be issued in the name of the individual person applying therefor, shall give the location of the tattoo parlor where the applicant will operate and shall not be transferable. 
(Code 1972, § 14-403) 
Secs. 18-179-18-205. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - GOING-OUT-OF-BUSINESS SALES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 18-206. - Exemptions. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to trustees selling under deeds of assignment; to sheriffs, constables or other public or court officers or any person acting under the license, direction or authority of any court, state or federal, selling goods, wares or merchandise in the course of official duties; to a merchant who has been conducting a business in the city continuously for at least one year immediately prior thereto under an ordinary merchant's license, and who is closing out his stock of goods, wares and merchandise and advertises as such; or to a merchant whose stock of goods, wares and merchandise has been damaged by fire, smoke, water or otherwise and the merchant advertises as such. 
(Code 1972, § 14-138) 
Secs. 18-207-18-225. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 18-226. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to advertise or conduct a sale for the purpose of discontinuing a retail business, or to modify the word "sale" in any advertisement with the words "going-out-of-business" or any other words which tend to insinuate that the retail business is to be discontinued and the merchandise liquidated unless such person obtains a permit to conduct such sale from the city manager. 
(Code 1972, § 14-131) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-223. 
Sec. 18-227. - Application; filing; inventory; issuance. 
(a)  Any person desiring a permit as required by this article shall make to the city manager an application. 
(b)  All applications for special sale permits shall be accompanied by an inventory, including the kind and quantity of all goods which are to be offered for sale during the sale and only the goods specified in the inventory list may be advertised or sold during the sale period. Goods not included on the inventory of special sale goods shall not be commingled with or added to the special sale goods. The city shall have the right to revoke a special sale permit upon proof that goods not appearing on the original inventory of special sale goods have been commingled with or added to the special sale goods. 
(c)  Each special sale permit shall be valid for a period of no longer than 60 days, and any extension of that time shall constitute a new special sale and shall require an additional permit and inventory. A maximum of one permit beyond the initial 60-day permit may be granted solely for the purpose of liquidating only those goods contained in the initial inventory list which remain unsold. 
(d)  Any person who advertises such sale shall conspicuously include in the advertisement the permit number assigned for the sale by the city and the effective dates of the sale as authorized in the permit. 
(Code 1972, § 14-132) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-224. 
Sec. 18-228. - Fees. 
    The applicant for a permit as required in this article shall pay a fee therefor of $15.00 per permit. 
(Code 1972, § 14-133) 
State Law reference- Permit fee, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-224. 
Secs. 18-229-18-245. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - YARD SALES 

Sec. 18-246. - Permit required. 
    Notwithstanding any other provisions of this Code, it shall be unlawful for any person to offer for sale any items of tangible property at sales, commonly known as "yard, garage, rummage, or backyard sales," whereby such sale is conducted on property on which is located a "dwelling" as defined in this Code, without first paying a fee of $5.00 to obtain a permit for the privilege of conducting such a sale. Such permit shall be issued by the city manager's office upon proper application at least 24 hours in advance of such sale. No more than four permits for one day each shall be issued per dwelling in any 12-month period, and no sale shall be held on Sunday. No permit shall be issued except upon sworn statement or affidavit of the applicant that only secondhand or used items owned by the applicant shall be offered for sale. Any person offering for sale such items without a permit, or who have been found guilty of giving a false statement of affidavit in order to obtain a permit, shall be subject to a fine as provided in section 1-11. 
(Code 1972, § 14-77; Ord. No. 05-50, § 1, 8-16-05; Ord. No. 05-62, § 1, 11-15-05) 
Sec. 18-247. - Charitable, civic, religious and nonprofit organizations; permit required. 
    Notwithstanding any other provisions of this Code, it shall be unlawful for any charitable, civic, religious, or nonprofit organization to offer for sale any items of tangible property at sales, commonly known as "yard, rummage, garage, or backyard sales," without first obtaining a permit for the privilege of conducting such a sale. Such permit shall be issued by the city manager's office upon proper application at least seven days in advance of such sale. No more than four such permits for one day each shall be issued per organization in any 12-month period. Any organization found guilty of giving a false statement in order to obtain a permit shall be subject to a fine as provided by section 1-11. 
(Code 1972, § 14-78)

ARTICLE II. - ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY[2] 

Footnotes:

Sec. 22-31. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    The authority means the Economic Development Authority of the City of Emporia, Virginia. 
(Code 1972, § 2-146; Ord. No. 15-32, 9-1-15) 
State Law reference- Code of Virginia, § 15.2-4902, Definitions. 
Sec. 22-32. - Created. 
(a)  There is hereby created a political subdivision of the commonwealth with such public and corporate powers as are set forth in the Industrial Development and Revenue Bond Act, including such powers as may be set forth from time to time in the state law. 
(b)  The name of the political subdivision created hereby shall be the Economic Development Authority of the City of Emporia, Virginia. 
(Code 1972, § 2-146; Ord. No. 15-32, 9-1-15) 
State Law reference- Code of Virginia, ch. 49, Industrial Development and Revenue Bond Act, §15.2-4903, Creation of industrial development authorities. 
Sec. 22-33. - Governed by board of directors; composition of board; appointment and terms of members. 
(b)  Appointments of the directors shall be for terms of four years, except appointments to fill vacancies which shall be for the unexpired terms. All terms of office shall be deemed to commence upon the date of the initial appointment to the authority. 
(c)  Each director shall, before entering upon his or her duties, take and subscribe the oath prescribed by state law and shall serve until their successors are appointed and qualified. 
(d)  No director shall be an officer or employee of the City of Emporia. Virginia. Every director shall, at the time of his or her appointment and thereafter, be a resident of Emporia or Greensville County. When a director ceases to be a resident of Emporia or Greensville County, the director's office shall be vacant and a new director may be appointed for the remainder of the term. 
(Code 1972, § 2-147; Ord. No. 15-32, 9-1-15) 
State Law reference- Code of Virginia, § 15.2-4904, Directors; qualifications; terms; vacancies; compensation and expenses; quorum; records; certification and distribution of report concerning bond issuance. 
Chapter 26 - COURTS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Judicial provisions, § 33 et seq. 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 
State Law reference- Criminal and traffic jurisdiction of general district courts, Code of Virginia, § 16.1-123.1; criminal jurisdiction of juvenile and domestic relations district courts, Code of Virginia, § 16.1-278.14. 

Sec. 26-1. - General district court. 
(a)  Established. There is established for the city a court which shall be known as the general district court. 
(b)  Jurisdiction. The general district judge shall have exclusive original jurisdiction to hear and determine all cases involving city ordinances, and all civil and criminal jurisdiction conferred on general district courts and courts not of record by the Charter and general law. 
(Code 1972, §§ 2-86, 2-87) 
Sec. 26-2. - Juvenile and domestic relations district court. 
(a)  Established. There is established a juvenile and domestic relations district court for the city. 
(b)  Jurisdiction. The juvenile and domestic relations district court of the city shall have the jurisdiction as set forth in state law governing the jurisdiction of such courts. 
(Code 1972, §§ 2-88, 2-89) 
State Law reference- Jurisdiction, Code of Virginia, § 16.1-241. 
Sec. 26-3. - Judges. 
(a)  Qualifications generally. The person appointed as general district judge for the city and the person appointed as judge of the juvenile and domestic relations district court of the city shall be a member of the state bar and a resident of the commonwealth. 
(b)  Qualifications as required by law. The general district judge and the judge of the juvenile and domestic relations district court shall qualify as such as required by law before entering into their duties. 
(Code 1972, §§ 2-90, 2-91) 
Sec. 26-4. - Assessment for local law library. 
(a)  Specified. There is hereby assessed the sum of $2.00 as a part of the costs incident to each civil action filed in the courts located within the boundaries of the city. 
(b)  Collection. Such assessment shall be collected by the clerk of the court in which the action is filed and remitted to the treasurer of the city, and held by such treasurer, subject to periodic disbursements per order of the circuit court to trustees appointed by order of the circuit court for the purposes set forth in state law. 
(c)  Location and regulation of library. The clerk of the county circuit court along with the trustees appointed by the order of the circuit court shall keep the law library in the county courthouse according to the provisions of state law and pursuant to rules and regulations as may be established by order of the circuit court. 
(Code 1972, § 1-8.1; Ord. No. 317-94, 6-21-94; Ord. No. 318-94, 9-6-94) 
State Law reference- Local law libraries in charge of circuit court clerks, Code of Virginia, § 42.1-65; assessment for law library as part of costs in civil actions, Code of Virginia, § 42.1-70. 
Sec. 26-5. - Assessment for courthouse construction, renovation or maintenance. 
(a)  Specified. There is hereby assessed the sum of $2.00 as a part of the fees taxed as costs in each civil, criminal and traffic case filed in the city general district and each case filed in the city juvenile and domestic relations court, and all cases arising out of the city filed in the county circuit court. 
(b)  Collection. The assessment described in subsection (a) of this section shall be collected by the clerk of the court in which the action is filed and remitted to the treasurer of the city and held by such treasurer subject to disbursements by the council for the construction, renovation or maintenance of a courthouse or jail and court-related facilities and to defray increases in the cost of heating, cooling, electricity and ordinary maintenance. The assessment provided for in this section shall be in addition to any other fees prescribed by law. 
(Code 1972, § 1-8.2; Ord. No. 316-94, 6-21-94; Ord. No. 319-94, 9-6-94) 
State Law reference- Authority for above section, Code of Virginia, § 14.1-133.2. 
Sec. 26-6. - Payment of fines and costs. 
    If any person does not pay a fine or costs imposed for violation of a city ordinance, the court shall follow the procedures established by law. 
(Code 1972, § 1-9) 
State Law reference- Payment of fines and costs on installment basis, etc., Code of Virginia, § 19.2-354 et seq. 
Sec. 26-7. - Assessment for courtroom security fee. 
    There is hereby assessed a fee of $10.00 as part of the cost in each criminal or traffic case in the city general district or circuit court in which the defendant is convicted of a violation of any statute or ordinance. The assessment shall be collected by the clerk of the court in which the case is heard and remitted to the city treasurer, to be appropriated by the city council to the sheriff's office for the funding of courthouse security personnel. The assessment hereby imposed shall be in addition to any other fees prescribed by law. 
(Ord. No. 06-58, 6-19-07) 
Sec. 26-8. - Jail processing fee. 
    There is hereby assessed a processing fee of $25.00 on any individual admitted to the Southside Regional Jail following conviction. The fee shall be ordered as a part of court costs collected by the clerk of court and remitted to the city treasurer. The fees shall be appropriated by city council to the Southside Regional Jail to defray the costs of processing arrested persons. 
(Ord. No. 09-55.1, 9-15-09) 
State Law reference- Processing fee may be imposed on certain individuals, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1613.1. 
Sec. 26-9. - Assessment for electronic summons system. 
    There is hereby assessed an electronic summons system fee of $5.00 as part of the costs in each criminal or traffic case in the city general district or circuit court in which the defendant is charged with a violation of any statute or ordinance. The assessment shall be collected by the clerk of the court in which the action is filed, remitted to the city treasurer, and held by such treasurer subject to appropriation by the city council to a local law-enforcement agency solely to fund software, hardware, and associated equipment costs for the implementation and maintenance of an electronic summons system. 
(Ord. No. 15-30, 8-18-15) 
State Law reference- Additional assessment for electronic summons system. Code of Virginia, §17.1-279.1

ARTICLE II. - DISTRICTS, VOTING PRECINCTS AND POLLING PLACES 

Sec. 30-31. - Authority of article. 
    Pursuant to the requirements of Article VII, Section 5 of the Constitution of Virginia and authority contained in Sections 24.2-304.1 and 24.2-311 of the Code of Virginia (1950), as amended, the election districts, voting precincts, and polling places for the City of Emporia are hereby created and established as set forth in this article. 
(Code 1972, § 6-21; Ord. No. 11-31, § 1, 12-6-11) 
State Constitution reference- Election of city governing bodies, art. VII, § 5. 
State Law reference- Composition of election districts and precincts, Code of Virginia, § 24.2-305; requirements for city precincts, Code of Virginia, § 24.2-307; requirements for polling places, Code of Virginia, § 24.2-310. 
Sec. 30-32. - Election districts. 
    The city shall be divided into seven election districts, whose boundaries shall be as follows: 
(1)  Election district 1: Starting at the entrance of Georgia-Pacific and Davis Street eastward to the corporate limits, then southward along the corporate limits which bears to the east, then bears to the south, then bears to the west to the Metcalf Branch, then southward across Meherrin River along Falling Run Creek, then westward along the corporate limits to Falling Run Road, then eastward to Brink Road, then from Brink Road northward along South Main Street to Adam Street, then eastward to Old Halifax Road, then northward to Lowground Road, then southeastward to the railroad tracks and along the railroad track northward to Greensville Avenue, then eastward along Greensville Avenue to Tillar Street, then southward to Grove Avenue, then eastward to a point approximately half way between South Oak Hill and Anchura Court, then northwest to the Meherrin River, then northward to Hicksford Avenue, then eastward to Center Street, then northward to High Street, then eastward to Lee Street, then northward to Monroe Avenue, then eastward to Franklin Street , then northward to Madison Avenue, then eastward to Broad Street, then northward to East Atlantic Street, then eastward to the southern entrance of Georgia-Pacific then northward across Georgia-Pacific to Davis Street, the point of the beginning. 
(2)  Election district 2: Starting at the intersection of Market Drive and Route 58 Bypass eastward to Halifax Street, then southward to Parham Street, then along Parham Street to Bethune Square, then along Bethune Square to Evans Street, then southward to Turner Street, then westward to Halifax Street, then southward to the Norfolk Southern Railroad, then westward to the intersection of Norfolk Southern Railroad and East Atlantic Street, then westward to North Main Street, then southward to Little Street, then along Little Street to Carroll Street, then westward to Taylor Street, then southward to West End Boulevard, then westward to Suiter Street, then northward to Carroll Street, then eastward to Pennsylvania Avenue (paper street), then northward to a point behind the first row of houses that border Norfolk Southern Railroad toward Walker Street, then eastward on Walker Street to Smith Street, then northward to West Atlantic Street, then westward to Market Drive, then northward to the point of the beginning. 
(3)  Election district 3: Starting at the intersection of Norfolk Southern Railroad and Interstate 95 eastward, then southward along Suiter Street toward West End Boulevard, then eastward to Taylor Street, then northward to Carroll Street then eastward to Main Street, then southward to Valley Street, then eastward to Halifax, then southward to Virginia Avenue, then eastward to CSX Railward, then southward to Hicksford Avenue, then eastward to Tillar Street, then southward to Greensville Avenue, then westward to Clay Street, then southward to Briggs Street, then westward to South Main Street, then westward along Jefferson Street to Ingleside Avenue, then northward to Church Street then, westward to Ashby Street, then northward to Brunswick Avenue, then westward to West Avenue, then southward to Jefferson Street, then westward to Everett Street, then northward to Brunswick Avenue, then eastward to West York Drive, then northward to York Drive, then eastward to along East York Drive to Shady Lane, then westward to Interstate 95, then northward to the point of the beginning. 
(4)  Election district 4: Starting at the intersection of Church Street and Interstate 95 along the City limits northward, then eastward, to the intersection of North Main Street and the City limits, then southward to Halifax Street, then southward to Route 58, then westward to Market Drive, then southward to West Atlantic Street, then eastward to Smith Drive, then southward to Walker Street, then westward to Walker Street (paper street), then southward to the houses north of Railroad Avenue (not including houses on Railroad Avenue), then westward to Pennsylvania Avenue, then southward to Norfolk Southern Railroad, then eastward to Interstate 95, then southward to Norfolk Southern Railroad, then eastward to Interstate 95, then southward to Shady Lane, then eastward to East York Drive, then southward to West York Drive, then southward to Brunswick Avenue, then westward to Echols Street, then southward to Church Street, then westward to the point of the beginning. 
(5)  Election district 5: Starting where North Main Street intersects with the City limits, then eastward and southward along the City limits to the Norfolk Southern Railroad, then westward to the intersection of Norfolk Southern Railroad and Route 58, then southward to the Davis Street, then westward along Davis Street to Deal Street, then westward to Center Street, then southward to Southampton Street, then westward along Southampton and Valley to Main Street, then northward to Carroll Street, then westward, to Little Street, then eastward to Main Street, then northward to Atlantic Street, then eastward to Norfolk Southern Railroad, then eastward to Halifax Street, then northward to Turner Street, then eastward to Evans Street, then northward to Bethune Square, then along Bethune Square to the intersection of Parham Street, then along Parham Street to Halifax Street, then northward to North Main Street, then northward to the City limits to the point of the beginning. 
(6)  Election district 6: Starting at the intersection of Interstate 95 and Route 611, then eastward to Everett Street, then southward to Jefferson Street, then eastward to West Avenue, then northward to Brunswick Avenue, then eastward to Ashby Street, then southward to Church Street, then eastward to Ingleside Avenue, then southward to Jefferson Street, then eastward to CSX Railroad, then southward to Lowground Road, then westward to Old Halifax Road, then southward to Adam Street then westward to South Main Street, then southward to Brink Road, then westward to Falling Run Road, then westward to the City limits, then westward along the City limits to the point of the beginning. 
(7)  Election district 7: Starting at the intersection of Deal Street and Davis Street, then northward as Davis Street bends to the east, to northern entrance of Georgia-Pacific property, then southward across Georgia Pacific to the Atlantic Street entrance of Georgia-Pacific, then westward to Broad Street, then southward to Madison Avenue, then westward to Franklin Street, then southward to Monroe Street, then westward to Lee Street, then southward to High Street, then westward to Center Street, then southward to Hicksford Avenue, then westward to the Meherrin River, then southward to a point approximately half-way between South Oak Hill Drive and Anchura Court on Grove Avenue, then westward to Tillar Street, then northward to Hicksford Avenue, then westward to CSX Railroad, then northward to Park Avenue, then westward to Halifax Street, then northward to Southampton Street, then eastward to Center Street, then northward to Deal Street, then eastward to Davis Street, which is the point of the beginning. 
(Code 1972, § 6-22; Ord. No. 01-22, §§ 1, 2, 10-30-01; Ord. No. 11-31, § 2, 12-6-11) 
Sec. 30-33. - Candidates. 
    One member of city council shall be elected from each district. Candidates seeking election to the city council shall be residents of the district for which they qualify to run and shall be elected solely by the voters of that district. The mayor of the City of Emporia shall continue to be elected at-large by the voters of the entire city. 
(Code 1972, § 6-23; Ord. No. 01-22, § 3, 10-30-01; Ord. No. 11-31, § 3, 12-6-11) 
Sec. 30-34. - Terms. 
    At the regularly scheduled election in November of 2014, one member of city council shall be elected from each of election districts 1, 4, 5, and 7 to serve four-year terms ending December 31, 2018. At the regularly scheduled election in November of 2012, one member of city council shall be elected from each of election districts 2, 3, and 6 to serve four-year terms ending December 31, 2016. 
(Code 1972, § 6-24; Ord. No. 01-22, § 4, 10-30-01; Ord. No. 11-31, § 4, 12-6-11) 
Sec. 30-35. - Voting precincts. 
    There shall be one voting precinct for each election district in the City of Emporia, and the boundaries of the election districts shall constitute the boundaries of the voting precincts of the city. 
(Code 1972, § 6-25; Ord. No. 01-22, § 5, 10-30-01; Ord. No. 11-31, § 5, 12-6-11) 
Sec. 30-36. - Polling places. 
    The polling place for each voting precinct in the city shall be as follows: 
(1)  Election district 1, voting precinct 1-1; Greensville Volunteer Rescue Squad Building, 513 South Main Street. 
(2)  Election district 2, voting precinct 2-1: Royal Baptist Church, 106 West Atlantic Street. 
(3)  Election district 3, voting precinct 3-1: Emporia Municipal Building, 201 South Main Street. 
(4)  Election district 4, voting precinct 4-1: Greensville County High School, 309 Harding Street. 
(5)  Election district 5, voting precinct 5-1: Emporia Volunteer Fire Department Building, 209 Halifax Street. 
(6)  Election district 6, voting precinct 6-1: Greensville County High School, 309 Harding Street. 
(7)  Election district 7, voting precinct 7-1: Emporia Volunteer Fire Department Building, 209 Halifax Street. 
(Code 1972, § 6-26; Ord. No. 01-22, § 6, 10-30-01; Ord. No. 11-31, § 6, 12-6-11; Ord. No. 15-24, 7-21-15) 
Sec. 30-37. - Central absentee precinct. 
    There is hereby established a permanent central absentee precinct in the City of Emporia. The central absentee precinct shall be located at 201 S. Main Street, Emporia, Virginia 23847 for the purpose of receiving, counting, and recording absentee ballots for all elections conducted in the city. 
(Ord. No. 17-13, 6-6-17) 
State Law reference- Code of Virginia, § 24.2-712.
