    Any person who shall operate, cause to be operated, or attempt to operate or cause to be operated any coin box telephone, parking meter, vending machine or other machine that operates, on the coin-in-the-slot principle, whether of like kind or not, designed only to receive lawful coin of the United States of America, in connection with the use or enjoyment of telephone or telegraph service, parking privilege or any other service, or the sale of merchandise or other property, by means of a slug, or any false, counterfeit, mutilated, sweated or foreign coin, or by any means, method, trick or device whatsoever, not authorized by the owner, lessee or licensee of such coin box telephone, parking meter, vending machine or other machine; or who shall obtain or receive telephone or telegraph service, parking privileges, merchandise, or any other service or property from any such coin box telephone, parking meter, vending machine or other machine, designed only to receive lawful coins of the United States of America, without depositing in or surrendering to such coin box telephone, parking meter, vending machine or other machine, lawful coins of the United States of America to the amount required therefor by the owner, lessee or licensee of such coin box telephone, parking meter, vending machine or other machine, shall be guilty of a class 3 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1972, § 14-95) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-179. 
Secs. 50-192-50-220. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - GAMING OR GAMBLING[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Gambling, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-325 et seq. 

Sec. 50-221. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Machine, apparatus or device means a slot machine or device that is adapted, or may readily be converted into one that is adapted, for use in such a way that, as a result of the insertion of any piece of money or coin or other object, such machine or device is caused to operate or may be operated, and by reason of any element of chance or of other outcome of such operation unpredictable by him the user: 
(1)  May receive or become entitled to receive any piece of money, credit, allowance or thing of value, or any check, slug, token or memorandum, whether of value or otherwise, which may be exchanged for any money, credit, allowance or thing of value, or which may be given in trade; or 
(2)  May secure additional chances or rights to use such machine, apparatus or device, irrespective of whether it may, apart from any element of chance or unpredictable outcome of such operation, also sell, deliver or present some merchandise, indication of weight, entertainment or other thing of value. 
Such machine, apparatus or device is no less a slot machine or device within the provisions of this article if it indicates beforehand the definite result of one or more operations but not of all operations. 
(Code 1972, § 14-116) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 50-222. - Betting, wagering, playing for money-Generally. 
    Any person who shall bet, wager or play at any game for money or other thing of value shall be guilty of a class 3 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1972, § 14-108) 
State Law reference- Illegal gambling, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-326. 
Sec. 50-223. - Same-In public place. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to bet or play at any table, bank or wheel of fortune in violation of section 50-222, or at any restaurant, race field, storehouse, tavern, inn or other public house, or in any street, highway, or other public place, or in any outhouse or other place where people resort for the purpose of gaming, to play at any game except billiards, bowls, chess, backgammon, drafts, dominoes, or a licensed game, or bet on the sides of those who play. 
(Code 1972, § 14-109) 
Sec. 50-224. - Same-Inclusions. 
    All houses and offices commonly known as public, and all gaming houses, are included within the meaning of section 50-223. Any room attached to any such public house, and commonly used for gaming, is also included, whether the same is kept closed or open. A business office after business hours, or a private residence, is not to be construed as within the meaning of a public house or place, unless such office after business hours, or private residence, is commonly used for gaming. 
(Code 1972, § 14-110) 
Sec. 50-225. - Same-Offense complete without betting. 
    In prosecutions under section 50-223 or 50-224, it shall not be necessary for the prosecution to prove that any money, or articles of value, or the representation of either, was bet at such game. 
(Code 1972, § 14-111) 
Sec. 50-226. - Keeping gaming bank, gaming tables, wheel of fortune, slot machine or pigeonhole table; seizure; disposition. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or exhibit for the purpose of gaming, any gaming table or bank of any name or description whatever or any table or bank used for gaming which has no name, any wheel of fortune or slot machine, or any pigeonhole table, whether the game or table is played with cards, dice or otherwise, or to be a partner or concerned in interest in the keeping or exhibiting of such table or bank. Any such table, bank or wheel of fortune and all the money, stakes or exhibits to allure persons to be at such table, bank or wheel may be seized by order of the court, or under warrant of a magistrate, and the monies so seized shall be forfeited to the city and the paraphernalia shall be burned; provided, however, that when any billiard or pool table or other paraphernalia, not inherently gambling paraphernalia, is so seized, the court may, in its discretion, award the same to some charitable organization upon the condition that it be used only for the purpose of recreation. 
(Code 1972, § 14-112) 
Sec. 50-227. - Occupant of premises permitting gaming tables, gaming bank or wheel of fortune. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person knowingly to permit a gaming table, gaming bank or wheel of fortune, such as is mentioned in section 50-226, to be kept or exhibited on any premises that he owns, leases or occupies, or keep a place resorted to for the purpose of gaming, or a place frequented for such purposes, or reside in such place for such purposes. 
(Code 1972, § 14-113) 
State Law reference- Permitting continuance of gambling place, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-329. 
Sec. 50-228. - Slot machines, punchboards, similar devices-Keeping or exhibiting for sale or use. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to: 
(1)  Keep or exhibit for sale or use, or have an interest in keeping or exhibiting for sale or use, any punchboard or similar device of any kind or description; slot machine or similar device of any kind, or character, or other device that operates on the coin-in-the-slot principle, in the operation of which any element of chance whatever may enter, or through and from which it may be possible for one person to get any article of more value than that which any other person could and would get, or through and from which the article or thing vended is not the fair equivalent in value, to the coin required to operate such machine or device; or 
(2)  Permit any such punchboard or slot machine or similar device to be kept or exhibited for use in his place of business or in any other place in the city. 
Such punchboard, slot machine or other device shall be deemed a gaming apparatus and shall be embraced within the provisions of the state search warrant laws, insofar as such laws relate to gaming apparatus. The possession of any such punchboard, slot machine, or other device shall be prima facie evidence of the use thereof. Any slot machine or device, that operates on the coin-in-the-slot principle and which does not uniformly return to the customer in each transaction the equivalent in value and kind of merchandise unaccompanied by coins, trade checks or other items of monetary value that it returned in each preceding transaction shall be deemed to embody the element of chance within the meaning of this section, even though the machine or device is so constructed as to indicate in advance of each transaction what it will dispense upon the deposit of the next coin or slug. 
(Code 1972, § 14-114) 
State Law reference- What may be searched and seized, Code of Virginia, § 19.2-53; to whom search warrant directed, Code of Virginia, § 19.2-56; disposition of property seized, Code of Virginia, § 19.2-58. 
Sec. 50-229. - Same-Manufacture, storage, possession, sale, rental, lease, loan, operation or maintenance; reception of income. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to: 
(1)  Manufacture, own, store, keep, possess, sell, rent, lease, let on shares, lend or give away, transport or expose for sale or lease, offer to sell, rent, lease, let on shares, lend or give away, permit the operation of, or permit to be placed, maintained, used or kept in any room, space or building of any kind, public or quasipublic or private, owned, leased or occupied by him or under his management or control any slot machine or device; or 
(2)  Make or permit to be made with any person any agreement, express or implied or in any other way, with reference to any slot machine or device, pursuant to which the user thereof, as a result of any element of chance or other unpredictable outcome, may become entitled to receive any money, credit, allowance or thing of value or additional chance or right to use such machine or device, or to receive any check, slug, token or memorandum entitling the holder to receive any money, credit, allowance or thing of value, whether through such machine automatically or by delivery in any manner. 
(Code 1972, § 14-115) 
Sec. 50-230. - Lotteries-Managing, buying or selling chances. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to: 
(1)  Set up, promote or be concerned in managing or drawing a lottery or raffle for money or other thing of value; 
(2)  Knowingly permit such lottery in any house under his control; 
(3)  Knowingly permit money or other property to be raffled for in such house, or to be won in such house, by throwing or using dice, or by any other game of chance; 
(4)  Knowingly permit the sale in such house of any chance or ticket in, or share of a ticket in, a lottery, or any writing, certificate, bill, token or other device, purporting or intended to guarantee or ensure to any person, or entitle him to a prize or share of, or interest in a prize to be drawn in a lottery; or 
(5)  For himself or another person buy, sell or transfer, or have in his possession for the purpose of sale or with intent to exchange, negotiate or transfer, or aid in selling, exchanging, negotiating or transferring, a chance or ticket in or share of a ticket in a lottery, or any such writing, certificate, bill, token or device. 
However, nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit the legal participation in the state lottery conducted by the commonwealth. 
(Code 1972, § 14-117) 
State Law reference- State Lottery Law, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-4000. 
Sec. 50-231. - Same-Certain acts not deemed "consideration." 
    In any prosecution under section 50-230, no consideration shall be deemed to have passed or been given because of any person's attendance upon the premises of another; his execution, mailing or delivery of an entry blank; his answering of questions, verbally or in writing; his witnessing of a demonstration or other proceeding; or any one or more thereof, where no charge is made to, paid by, or any purchase required of him in connection therewith. 
(Code 1972, § 14-118) 
Sec. 50-232. - Same-Forfeiture of money or other things of value drawn and property used; innocent owners or lienors. 
    All money and things of value drawn or proposed to be drawn by an inhabitant of this city and all money or things of value received by such person by reason of his being the owner or holder of a ticket or share of a ticket in any lottery or pretended lottery, contrary to this article, and all money, gambling paraphernalia, office equipment and all other personal property of any kind or character used in connection with the promotion, operation or conduct of any lottery or attempted lottery shall be forfeited to the city and may be seized by an officer and held to await proceedings for condemnation, provided that such forfeiture shall not extinguish the rights of any person without knowledge of the illegal use of such property who is the lawful owner or who has a lien on the property which has been perfected in the manner provided by law. The money or other personal property so forfeited shall be disposed of as provided by law. 
(Code 1972, § 14-119) 
Secs. 50-233-50-260. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - OBSCENITY[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Obscenity and related offenses, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-372 et seq. 

Sec. 50-261. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Obscene means that which, considered as a whole, has as its dominant theme or purpose an appeal to the prurient interest in sex, that is, a shameful or morbid interest in nudity, sexual conduct, sexual excitement, excretory functions or products thereof or sadomasochistic abuse, and which goes substantially beyond customary limits of candor in description or representation of such matters and which, taken as a whole, does not have serious literary, artistic, political or scientific value. 
(Code 1972, § 14-170) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-372. 
Sec. 50-262. - Production, publication, sale, possession of obscene items. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person knowingly to: 
(1)  Prepare any obscene item for the purposes of sale or distribution; 
(2)  Print, copy, manufacture, produce, or reproduce any obscene item for purposes of sale or distribution; 
(3)  Publish, sell, rent, lend, transport in intrastate commerce, or distribute or exhibit any obscene item, or offer to do any of these things; or 
(4)  Have in his possession with intent to sell, rent, lend, transport, or distribute any obscene item. 
Possession in public or in a public place of any obscene item shall be deemed prima facie evidence of a violation of this section. 
(b)  For the purposes of this section, the word "distribute" shall mean delivery in person, by mail, messenger or by any other means by which obscene items may pass from one person to another. 
(Code 1972, § 14-171) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-374. 
Sec. 50-263. - Obscene items enumerated. 
    Obscene items shall include: 
(1)  Any obscene book; 
(2)  Any obscene leaflet, pamphlet, magazine, booklet, picture, painting, bumper sticker, drawing, photograph, film, negative, slide, motion picture, videotape recording; or 
(3)  Any obscene figure, object, article, instrument, novelty device, or recording or transcription used or intended to be used in disseminating any obscene song, ballad, words, or sounds. 
(Code 1972, § 14-172) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-373. 
Sec. 50-264. - Obscene exhibitions and performances. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person knowingly to: 
(1)  Produce, promote, prepare, present, manage, direct, carry on or participate in, any obscene exhibitions or performances, including the exhibition or performance of any obscene motion picture, play, drama, show, entertainment, exposition, tableau or scene; provided, however, that no employee of any person or legal entity operating a theatre, garden, building, structure, room or place which presents such obscene exhibition or performance shall be subject to prosecution under this section if the employee is not the manager of the theatre or an officer of such entity, and has no financial interest in such theatre other than receiving salary and wages; or 
(2)  Own, lease or manage any theatre, garden, building, structure, room or place and lease, let, lend or permit such theatre, garden, building, structure, room or place to be used for the purpose of presenting such obscene exhibition or performance or to fail to post prominently therein the name and address of a person resident in the locality who is the manager of such theatre, garden, building, structure, room or place. 
(Code 1972, § 14-173) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-375. 
Sec. 50-265. - Advertising obscene items, exhibitions or performances. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person knowingly to prepare, print, publish, or circulate, or cause to be prepared, printed, published or circulated, any notice or advertisement of any obscene item proscribed in this article, or of any obscene performance or exhibition proscribed in this article, stating or indicating where such obscene item, exhibition, or performance may be purchased, obtained, seen or heard. 
(Code 1972, § 14-174) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-376. 
Sec. 50-266. - Placards, posters, banners, bills, writing or pictures. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, knowingly to expose, place, display, post, exhibit, paint, print, or mark or cause to be exposed, placed, displayed, posted, exhibited, painted, printed or marked, in or on any building, structure, billboard, wall or fence, or on any street, or in or upon any public place, any placard, poster, banner, bill, writing, or picture which is obscene, or which advertises or promotes any obscene item proscribed in this article or any obscene exhibition or performance proscribed in this article or knowingly to permit the same to be displayed on property belonging to or controlled by him. 
(Code 1972, § 14-175) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-377. 
Sec. 50-267. - Coercing acceptance of obscene articles or publications. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, as a condition to any sale, allocation, consignment or delivery for resale of any paper, magazine, book, periodical or publication, to require that the purchaser or consignee receive for resale any other article, book, or other publication which is obscene; or for any person to deny or threaten to deny any franchise or impose or threaten to impose any penalty, financial or otherwise, by reason of the failure or refusal of any person to accept such articles, books, or publications, or by reason of the return thereof. 
(Code 1972, § 14-176) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-378. 
Sec. 50-268. - Photographs, slides and motion pictures. 
    Every person who knowingly: 
(1)  Photographs himself or any other person, for purposes of preparing an obscene film, photograph, negative, slide or motion picture for purposes of sale or distribution; or 
(2)  Models, poses, acts, or otherwise assists in the preparation of any obscene film, photograph, negative, slide or motion picture for purposes of sale or distribution; 
shall be guilty of a class 3 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1972, § 14-177) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-382. 
Sec. 50-269. - Indecent exposure. 
    Every person who intentionally makes an obscene display or exposure of his person, or the private parts thereof, in any public place, or in any place where others are present, or procures another to so expose himself, shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. No person shall be deemed to be in violation of this section for breastfeeding a child in any public place or any place where others are present. 
(Code 1972, § 14-178) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-387. 
Sec. 50-270. - Employing or permitting minor to assist in offense. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person knowingly to hire, employ, use or permit any minor to do or assist in doing any act or thing constituting an offense under this article. 
(Code 1972, § 14-179) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-379. 
Sec. 50-271. - Exceptions to article. 
    Nothing contained in this article shall be construed to apply to: 
(1)  The purchase, distribution, exhibition, or loan of any book, magazine, or other printed manuscript material by any library, school, or institution of higher learning, supported by public appropriation; 
(2)  The purchase, distribution, exhibition, or loan of any work of art by any museum of fine arts, school, or institution of higher learning, supported by public appropriation; or 
(3)  The exhibition or performance of any play, drama, tableau, or motion picture by any theater, museum of fine arts, school, or institution of higher learning, supported by public appropriation. 
(Code 1972, § 14-180) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-383. 
Secs. 50-272-50-300. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - OFFENSES AGAINST PROPERTY 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 50-301. - Lienholders unaffected. 
    The provisions of this article relating to trespass, injury or taking away shall not apply to a bona fide repossession of a vehicle, aircraft, boat or vessel by the holder of a lien on such vehicle, aircraft, boat or vessel, or by agents or employees of such lienholder. 
(Code 1972, § 14-191) 
Sec. 50-302. - Petit larceny. 
    Any person who: 
(1)  Commits larceny from the person of another of money or other thing of value of less than $5.00; or 
(2)  Commits simple larceny not from the person of another of goods and chattels of the value of less than $200.00, except as provided in state law, shall be deemed guilty of petit larceny, which shall be punishable as a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1972, § 14-192) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-96; grand larceny, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-95(iii). 
Sec. 50-303. - Injuring-Any property or monument. 
    If any person unlawfully destroys, defaces, damages or removes without the intent to steal any property, real or personal, not his own, or breaks down, destroys, defaces, damages or removes without the intent to steal, any monument erected for the purpose of marking the site of any engagement fought during the War Between The States, or for the purpose of designating the boundaries of any city, town, tract of land, or any tree marked for that purpose, he shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor if the value of or damage to the property or monument is less than $1,000.00. The amount of loss caused by the destruction, defacing, damage or removal of such property or monument may be established by proof of the fair market cost of repair or fair market replacement value. 
(Code 1972, § 14-193) 
Cross reference- Removal of sand or earth from street or sidewalk, § 62-8; injuring or destroying trees, § 82-34. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-137. 
Sec. 50-304. - Same-Curbs and gutters, sidewalks, streets or street markers. 
    It shall be unlawful for any unauthorized person to injure, damage or deface any curb and gutter, sidewalk, street, or street marker. 
(Code 1972, § 14-194) 
Sec. 50-305. - Same-Tampering with fire hydrants. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to tamper in any way with any fire hydrants. 
(Code 1972, § 14-195) 
Cross reference- Tampering with water department equipment, § 78-37. 
Sec. 50-306. - Same-Land and water vehicles. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, individually or in association with one or more others, to wilfully break, injure, tamper with or remove any part of any vehicle, aircraft, boat or vessel for the purpose of injuring, defacing or destroying such vehicle, aircraft, boat or vessel, or temporarily or permanently preventing its useful operation, or for any purpose against the will or without the consent of the owner of such vehicle, aircraft, boat or vessel, or in any other manner willfully or maliciously interfere with or prevent the running or operation of such vehicle, aircraft, boat or vessel. 
(Code 1972, §§ 14-196, 20-5) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-146. 
Sec. 50-307. - Receiving or concealing stolen property. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to buy or receive from another person, or aid in concealing, any stolen goods or other thing, the subject of petit larceny, knowing the same to have been stolen. Such person shall be deemed guilty of larceny thereof, and may be proceeded against, although the principal offender be not convicted. 
(Code 1972, § 14-203) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-108. 
Secs. 50-308-50-335. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - TRESPASS AND SIMILAR OFFENSES 

Sec. 50-336. - Trespass after having been forbidden to do so; penalties for violation of section. 
    If any person without authority of law goes upon or remains upon the lands, buildings or premises of another, or any portion or area thereof, after having been forbidden to do so, either orally or in writing, by the owner, lessee, custodian or other person lawfully in charge thereof, or after having been forbidden to do so by a sign or signs posted by such persons or by the holder of any easement or other right-of-way authorized by the instrument creating such interest to post such signs on such lands, structures, premises or portion or area thereof at a place or places where it or they may be reasonably seen, or if any person, whether he is the owner, tenant or otherwise entitled to the use of such land, building or premises, goes upon, or remains upon such land, building or premises after having been prohibited from doing so by a court of competent jurisdiction by an order or an ex parte order issued pursuant to state law, and after having been served with such order, he shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. This section shall not be construed to affect in any way designated provisions of state law on trespass. 
(Code 1972, § 14-197) 
State Law reference- Preliminary protective order, Code of Virginia, § 16.1-253; preliminary protective orders in cases of family abuse, Code of Virginia, § 16.1-253.1; disposition of children, Code of Virginia, §§ 16.1-278.2-16.1-278.6, 16.1-278.8, 16.1-278.14, 16.1-278.15; order of protection in cases of family abuse, Code of Virginia, § 16.1-279.1; similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-119; trespass provisions, Code of Virginia, §§ 18.2-132-18.2-136; court may make orders pending suit for divorce, custody, visitation, etc., Code of Virginia, § 20-103. 
Sec. 50-336.1. - Designation of police to enforce trespass violations. 
    The owner of any real property in the City of Emporia may designate the city of police department as a "person lawfully in charge of his property" for the purpose of forbidding another to go on or remain upon the lands, buildings or premises of the owner as specified in the designation. Any such designation by a landowner in the city shall be in writing and remain on file with the City of Emporia Police Department. 
(Ord. No. 99-8, 8-3-99) 
Sec. 50-337. - Entering or setting in motion, vehicle, aircraft, boat, locomotive or rolling stock of railroad; exceptions. 
    Any person who shall, without the consent of the owner or person in charge of a vehicle, aircraft, boat, vessel, locomotive or other rolling stock of a railroad, climb into or upon such vehicle, aircraft, boat, vessel, locomotive or other rolling stock of a railroad, with intent to commit any crime, malicious mischief, or injury thereto, or who, while a vehicle, aircraft, boat, vessel, locomotive or other rolling stock of a railroad is at rest and unattended, shall attempt to manipulate any of the levers and starting crank or other device, brakes or mechanism thereof or to set into motion such vehicle, aircraft, boat, vessel, locomotive or other rolling stock of a railroad, with the intent to commit any crime, malicious mischief, or injury thereto, shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor, except that such provision shall not apply when any such act is done in an emergency or in furtherance of public safety or by or under the direction of an officer in the regulation of traffic or performance of any other official duty. 
(Code 1972, §§ 14-198, 20-5) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-147. 
Sec. 50-338. - Instigating trespass by others; preventing service to persons. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to solicit, urge, encourage, exhort, instigate or procure another or others to go upon or remain upon the lands, buildings or premises of another, or any part, portion or area thereof, knowing such other person to have been forbidden, either orally or in writing, to do so by the owner, lessee, custodian or other person lawfully in charge thereof, or knowing such other person to have been forbidden to do so by a sign posted on such lands, buildings, premises or part, portion or area thereof at a place where it may reasonably be seen; or for any person, on such lands, buildings, premises or part, portion or area thereof to prevent or seek to prevent the owner, lessee, custodian, person in charge or any of his employees from rendering service to any person not so forbidden. 
(Code 1972, § 14-199) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-120. 
Sec. 50-339. - Peeping or spying into structure occupied as dwelling. 
    If any person enters upon the property of another and secretly or furtively peeps, spies or attempts to peep or spy into or through a window, door or other aperture of any building, structure, or other enclosure of any nature occupied or intended for occupancy as a dwelling, whether or not such building, structure or enclosure is permanently situated or transportable and whether or not such occupancy is permanent or temporary, such person shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1972, § 14-200) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-130. 
Sec. 50-340. - Trespass at night upon church or school property. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, without the consent of some person authorized to give such consent, to go or enter upon, in the nighttime, the premises or property of any church or upon any school property for any purpose other than to attend a meeting or service held or conducted in such church or school property. Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a class 3 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1972, § 14-201) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-128. 
Sec. 50-341. - Entering property of another for purpose of damaging it. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to enter the land, dwelling, outhouse or any other building of another for the purpose of damaging such property or any of the contents thereof or in any manner to interfere with the rights of the owner, user or the occupant thereof to use such property free from interference. Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. However, if a person intentionally selects the property entered because of the race, religious conviction, color or national origin of the owner, user or occupant of the property, the penalty, upon conviction, shall include a mandatory, minimum term of confinement of at least six months, 30 days of which shall not be suspended, in whole or in part. 
(Code 1972, § 14-202) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-121. 
Secs. 50-342-50-371. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - TELEPHONE; CITIZENS BAND RADIO 

Sec. 50-372. - Use of profane, threatening or indecent language over public airways. 
    If any person shall use obscene, vulgar, profane, lewd, lascivious, or indecent language, or make any suggestion or proposal of an obscene nature, or threaten any illegal or immoral act with the intent to coerce, intimidate, or harass any person, over any telephone or citizens band radio, in this city, he shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1972, § 14-49) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-427. 
Sec. 50-373. - Duty of telephone companies; notices in directories. 
(a)  It shall be the duty, on pain of contempt of court, of each telephone company in this commonwealth to furnish immediately in response to a subpoena issued by a circuit court such information as it, its officers and employees may possess which, in the opinion of the court, may aid in the apprehension of persons suspected of violating the provisions of this article or the provisions of section 50-9. 
(b)  Every telephone directory distributed to the public which lists the calling numbers of telephones or of any telephone exchange located in this commonwealth shall contain a notice which explains the offenses made punishable under this article, such notice to be printed in type which conforms with and is comparable to other type on the same page, and to be placed in a prominent place in such directory. Any violation of this subsection shall be punishable as a class 4 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1972, § 14-49) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-431. 
Secs. 50-374-50-400. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - SEX OFFENSES 

Sec. 50-401. - Adultery defined; penalty. 
    Any person, being married, who voluntarily shall have sexual intercourse with any person not his or her spouse shall be guilty of adultery, punishable as a class 4 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1972, § 14-216) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-365. 
Sec. 50-402. - Fornication. 
    Any person, not being married, who voluntarily shall have sexual intercourse with any other person, shall be guilty of fornication, punishable as a class 4 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1972, § 14-217) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-344. 
Sec. 50-403. - Lewd and lascivious cohabitation. 
    If any persons, not married to each other, lewdly and lasciviously associate and cohabit together, or, whether married or not, be guilty of open and gross lewdness and lasciviousness, each of them shall be guilty of a class 3 misdemeanor. Upon a repetition of the offense, and conviction, each of them shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1972, § 14-218) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-345. 
Sec. 50-404. - Being a prostitute or prostitution. 
(a)  Any person who, for money or its equivalent, commits adultery, fornication or a crime against nature, or offers to commit adultery, fornication or a crime against nature and thereafter does any substantial act in furtherance thereof, shall be guilty of being a prostitute, or prostitution, which shall be punishable as a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(b)  Any person who offers money or its equivalent to another for the purpose of engaging in sexual acts as enumerated in subsection (a) of this section and thereafter does any substantial act in furtherance thereof shall be guilty of solicitation of prostitution and shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1972, § 14-219) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-346; crimes against nature, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-361. 
Sec. 50-405. - Residing in or frequenting bawdy place; "bawdy place" defined. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to keep any bawdy place, or to reside in or at or visit, for immoral purposes, any such bawdy place. Each and every day such bawdy place shall be kept, resided in or visited, shall constitute a separate offense. In a prosecution under this section the general reputation of the place may be proved. As used in this section, "bawdy place" shall mean any place within or without any building or structure which is used or is to be used for lewdness, assignation or prostitution. 
(Code 1972, §§ 14-220, 14-221) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-347. 
Sec. 50-406. - Aiding prostitution or illicit sexual intercourse. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person or any officer, employee or agent of any firm, association or corporation, with knowledge of, or good reason to believe, the immoral purpose of such visit, to take or transport or assist in taking or transporting, or offer to take or transport on foot or in any way, any person to a place, whether within or without any building or structure, used or to be used for the purpose of lewdness, assignation or prostitution within this commonwealth; or procure or assist in procuring for the purpose of illicit sexual intercourse, or any crime against nature, or to give any information or direction to any person with intent to enable such person to commit an act of prostitution. 
(Code 1972, § 14-222) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-348; crimes against nature, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-361. 
Sec. 50-407. - Using vehicles to promote prostitution or unlawful sexual intercourse. 
    It shall be unlawful for any owner or chauffeur of any vehicle, with knowledge or reason to believe the same is to be used for such purpose, to use the same or to allow the same to be used for the purposes of prostitution or unlawful sexual intercourse, or to aid or promote such prostitution or unlawful sexual intercourse by the use of any such vehicle. 
(Code 1972, § 14-223) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-349. 
Sec. 50-408. - Confinement of convicted prostitutes and persons violating sections 50-405 through 50-407. 
    Every person convicted of being a prostitute and every person convicted of violating any of the provisions of sections 50-405 through 50-407 shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor; provided, however, that in any case in which a city or county farm or hospital is available for the confinement of persons so convicted, confinement may be in such farm or hospital, in the discretion of the court or judge. 
(Code 1972, § 14-224) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-350. 
Chapter 54 - PLANNING[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; buildings and building regulations, ch. 14; community development, ch. 22; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 62; subdivisions, ch. 66; utilities, ch. 78; zoning, ch. 90. 
State Law reference- Planning, subdivision of land and zoning, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-427 et seq.; local planning commission, Code of Virginia, §§ 15.1-427.1 et seq., 15.1-437 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 54-1-54-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PLANNING COMMISSION[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 54-31. - Creation; composition; appointment and terms of members. 
(a)  There is hereby created a city planning commission, consisting of nine members, appointed by the council, all of whom shall be residents of the city, and who shall be qualified by knowledge and experience to make decisions on questions of community growth and development. At least one-half of such members shall be owners of real property. 
(b)  One member of the planning commission may be a member of the council, and one member may be a member of the administrative branch of government of the city. The term of each of these two members shall be co-extensive with the term of office to which he has been elected or appointed, unless the city council, at the first regular meeting each year, appoints others to serve as their representatives. The remaining members, called "citizen members" of the planning commission shall serve terms of four years each. 
(Code 1972, § 2-103; Ord. No. 15-33, 9-1-15) 
State Law reference- Code of Virginia, § 15.221, Creation of local planning commissions; participation in planning district commissions or joint local commissions. § 15.2-2212, Qualifications, appointment, removal, terms and compensation of members of local planning commissions. 
Sec. 54-32. - Filling vacancies. 
    Vacancies on the planning commission shall be filled by appointment for the unexpired term only. 
(Code 1972, § 2-104) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-437. 
Sec. 54-33. - Compensation of members. 
    All members of the planning commission shall serve as such without compensation. 
(Code 1972, § 2-105) 
State Law reference- Compensation, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-437. 
Sec. 54-34. - Removal of members. 
    Any member of the planning commission may be removed for malfeasance in office. 
(Code 1972, § 2-106) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-437. 
Sec. 54-35. - Officers generally. 
    The planning commission shall elect its chairman and vice-chairman from among the citizen members, for a term of one year, who shall be eligible for reelection. The planning commission may create and fill such other offices as it may deem necessary. 
(Code 1972, § 2-107) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-442. 
Sec. 54-36. - Secretary. 
    The city manager or his designee shall act as secretary to the planning commission if the planning commission shall so require. 
(Code 1972, § 2-108) 
Sec. 54-37. - Appointment of employees. 
    The planning commission shall appoint such employees as it may deem necessary for its work. 
(Code 1972, § 2-109) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-442. 
Sec. 54-38. - Meetings. 
(a)  The planning commission shall hold at least one regular meeting in each year. Special meetings of the planning commission may be called by the chairman or by two members upon written request to the secretary. The secretary shall mail to all members, at least five days in advance of a special meeting, a written notice fixing the time and place of the meeting and the purpose thereof. 
(b)  Written notice of a special meeting is not required if the time of the special meeting has been fixed at a regular meeting, or if all members are present at the special meeting or file a written waiver of notice. 
(Code 1972, § 2-110) 
State Law reference- Meetings, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-439. 
Sec. 54-39. - Quorum. 
    A majority of the members shall constitute a quorum, and no action of the planning commission shall be valid unless authorized by a majority vote of those present and voting. 
(Code 1972, § 2-111) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-440. 
Sec. 54-40. - Rules for transaction of business. 
    The planning commission shall adopt rules for the transaction of its business. 
(Code 1972, § 2-112) 
Sec. 54-41. - Records. 
    The planning commission shall keep a record of its resolutions, transactions, findings and determinations, which record shall be a public record. 
(Code 1972, § 2-113) 
Sec. 54-42. - Expenditures. 
    The expenditures of the planning commission, exclusive of gifts or grants to the planning commission, shall be within the amounts duly appropriated by the council for that purpose, and subject to all restrictions provided by law. 
(Code 1972, § 2-114) 
Sec. 54-43. - Attendance of members at planning conferences. 
    Members of the planning commission, when duly authorized by the planning commission, may attend planning conferences or meetings of planning institutes or hearings upon pending planning legislation, and may visit other communities. The planning commission may, by resolution spread upon its minutes, pay the reasonable traveling expenses incident to such attendance or visits. 
(Code 1972, § 2-115) 
Sec. 54-44. - Furnishing of information by public officials. 
    All public officials shall, upon request, furnish to the planning commission, within a reasonable time, such available information as it may require for its work. 
(Code 1972, § 2-117) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-444; local planning commission, Code of Virginia, §§ 15.1-427.1 et seq., 15.1-437 et seq. 
Sec. 54-45. - Powers generally. 
    To effectuate the state law, the planning commission shall: 
(1)  Exercise general supervision of, and make regulations for, the administration of its affairs; 
(2)  Prescribe rules pertaining to its investigations and hearings; 
(3)  Supervise its fiscal affairs and responsibilities, under rules and regulations as prescribed by the council; 
(4)  Keep a complete record of its proceedings; and be responsible for the custody and preservation of its papers and documents; 
(5)  Make recommendations and periodic reports to the council concerning the operation of the planning commission and the status of planning within its jurisdiction; 
(6)  Prepare, publish and distribute reports, ordinances and other material relating to its activities; 
(7)  Prepare and submit an annual budget in the manner prescribed by the council; and 
(8)  If deemed advisable, establish an advisory committee. 
(Code 1972, § 2-118) 
State Law reference- Planning, subdivision of land and zoning, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-427 et seq. 
Sec. 54-46. - Contracting with city planners and other consultants. 
    The planning commission may contract with city planners, engineers, architects and other consultants for services it may require. 
(Code 1972, § 2-119) 
Sec. 54-47. - Right of entry. 
    The planning commission or its members, officers and employees in the performance of their functions may enter upon any land at reasonable times and make examinations and surveys and place and maintain necessary monuments and marks thereon. 
(Code 1972, § 2-120) 
Sec. 54-48. - Historical landmarks, statuary and works of art. 
    The planning commission shall have the power to control, preserve and care for historical landmarks and to control the design and location of statuary and other works of art, which are or may become the property of the city, and the removal, relocation and alteration of any such works belonging to the city. 
(Code 1972, § 2-121) 
Sec. 54-49. - Design of harbors, bridges and other public structures. 
    The planning commission shall have the power to make suggestions concerning the designs of harbors, bridges, viaducts, street fixtures and other public structures and appurtenances. 
(Code 1972, § 2-122) 
Sec. 54-50. - Programs for public structures and improvements. 
    The planning commission shall, from time to time, recommend to the appropriate public officials programs for public structures and improvements and for the financing thereof. 
(Code 1972, § 2-123) 
Sec. 54-51. - Performance of functions of zoning commission; adoption and operation of zoning plan and ordinance. 
    In preparing any zoning plan, the planning commission shall perform all the functions of a zoning commission as provided by law, and the zoning plan and ordinance shall be adopted and be operative in the manner provided by law. 
(Code 1972, § 2-124) 
State Law reference- Zoning, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-486 et seq. 
Secs. 54-52-54-65. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - COMPREHENSIVE PLAN[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Comprehensive plan, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-446.1 et seq. 

Sec. 54-66. - Purpose of division. 
    The comprehensive plan shall be made with the general purpose of guiding and accomplishing a coordinated, adjusted and harmonious development of the city and its environs which will, in accordance with existing and future needs, best promote public health, safety, morals, order, convenience and general welfare, as well as efficiency and economy in the process of development. 
(Code 1972, § 2-137) 
Sec. 54-67. - Power to make and adopt; required details; partial adoption and publication generally; amendments. 
(a)  The planning commission shall have the power and duty to make and adopt a comprehensive plan for the physical development of the city, which, with the accompanying maps, plats, charts and descriptive matter, shall show the planning commission's recommendations for the development of the territory covered by the plan, including, among other things, the general location, character and extent of streets, viaducts, subways, bridges, waterways, waterfronts, beaches, boulevards, parkways, playgrounds, squares, parks, aviation fields and other public ways, grounds and open spaces and the general location of public buildings and other public property. It shall also show the planning commission's recommendations for the removal, relocation, widening, narrowing, vacating, abandonment, change of use or extension of existing ways, grounds, open spaces, buildings, property, utilities or terminals, as well as a zoning plan for the control of the height, area, bulk, location and use of buildings and premises. 
(b)  In the preparation of a comprehensive plan the planning commission shall make careful and comprehensive surveys and studies of the existing conditions and trends of growth, and of the probable future requirements of its territory and inhabitants. The comprehensive plan shall be made with the purpose of guiding and accomplishing a coordinated, adjusted and harmonious development of the territory which will, in accordance with present and probable future needs and resources, best promote the health, safety, morals, order, convenience, prosperity and general welfare of the inhabitants. 
(c)  The comprehensive plan shall be general in nature, in that it shall designate the general or approximate location, character, and extent of each feature shown on the plan and shall indicate where existing lands or facilities are proposed to be extended, widened, removed, relocated, vacated, narrowed, abandoned, or changed in use as the case may be. 
(d)  Such plan, with the accompanying maps, plats, charts, and descriptive matter, shall show the commission's long range recommendations for the general development of the territory covered by the comprehensive plan, including the location of existing or proposed recycling centers. It may include, but need not be limited to: 
(1)  The designation of areas for various types of public and private development and use, such as different kinds of residential, business, industrial, agricultural, conservation, recreation, public service, floodplain and drainage, and other areas; 
(2)  The designation of a system of transportation facilities such as streets, roads, highways, parkways, railways, bridges, viaducts, waterways, airports, ports, terminals, and other like facilities; 
(3)  The designation of a system of community service facilities such as parks, forests, schools, playgrounds, public buildings and institutions, hospitals, community centers, waterworks, sewage disposal or waste disposal areas, and the like; 
(4)  The designation of historical areas and areas for urban renewal or other treatment; 
(5)  The designation of areas for the implementation of reasonable ground water protection measures; 
(6)  An official map, a capital improvements program, a subdivision ordinance, a zoning ordinance and zoning district maps and agricultural and forestal district maps, where applicable; and 
(7)  The designation of areas for the implementation of measures to promote the construction and maintenance of affordable housing, sufficient to meet the current and future needs of residents of all levels of income in the locality while considering the current and future needs of the planning district within which the locality is situated. 
(e)  As the work of preparing the comprehensive plan progresses, the planning commission may, from time to time, recommend, and the council approve and adopt, parts thereof. Any such part shall cover one or more major sections or divisions of the county or city or one or more functional matters. 
(f)  After the adoption of a comprehensive plan, all amendments to it shall be recommended, and approved and adopted, respectively, as required by state law. If the council desires an amendment it may direct the planning commission to prepare an amendment and submit it to public hearing within 60 days after formal written request by the council. 
(Code 1972, § 2-131) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, §§ 15.1-446.1, 15.1-452, 15.1-453; advertisement of plans, ordinances, etc., joint public hearings, written notice of certain amendments, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-431. 
Sec. 54-68. - Adoption of whole or successive parts. 
(a)  The planning commission may adopt the plan as a whole by a single resolution or may, by successive resolutions, adopt successive parts of the plan, such parts corresponding with major geographical sections or geographical or topographical divisions of the city or with functional subdivisions of the subject matter of the comprehensive plan, and may adopt any amendment or extension thereof or addition thereto. 
(b)  Prior to the recommendation of a comprehensive plan or any part thereof, the planning commission shall give notice and hold a public hearing on the plan, after notice as required by state law. After such public hearing has been held, the planning commission may approve, amend and approve, or disapprove the comprehensive plan. Upon approval of the comprehensive plan, the planning commission shall by resolution recommend the plan to the council. 
(c)  The adoption of the plan or of any such part, amendment, extension or addition shall be by resolution of the planning commission, carried by the affirmative votes of not less than a majority of the full membership of the planning commission. The resolution shall refer expressly to the maps and descriptive and other matter intended by the planning commission to form the whole or part of the comprehensive plan, and the action taken shall be recorded on the maps and plan and descriptive matter by the identifying signature of the chairman or secretary of the planning commission. An attested copy of the comprehensive plan or any adopted part of such plan shall then be certified to council and to the clerk of the court where deeds are recorded. 
(Code 1972, § 2-132) 
State Law reference- Advertisement of plans, ordinances, etc., joint public hearings, written notice of certain amendments, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-431. 
Sec. 54-69. - Legal status. 
(a)  Whenever the planning commission shall have recommended a comprehensive plan or part thereof for the city and such plan shall have been approved and adopted by the council, it shall control the general or approximate location, character and extent of each feature shown on the plan. Thereafter, unless such feature is already shown on the adopted comprehensive plan or part thereof or is deemed so under subsection (d) of this section, no street or connection to an existing street, park or other public area, public building or public structure, public utility facility or public service corporation facility other than railroad facility, whether publicly or privately owned, shall be constructed, established or authorized, unless and until the general location or approximate location, character, and extent thereof has been submitted to and approved by the planning commission as being substantially in accord with the adopted comprehensive plan or part thereof. In connection with any such determination the planning commission may, and at the direction of the council shall, hold a public hearing, after notice as required by state law. 
(b)  The planning commission shall communicate its findings to the council, indicating its approval or disapproval with written reasons therefor. The council may overrule the action of the planning commission by a vote of a majority of the membership thereof. Failure of the planning commission to act within 60 days of such submission, unless such time shall be extended by the council, shall be deemed approval. The owners or their agents may appeal the decision of the planning commission to the council within ten days after the decision of the planning commission. The appeal shall be by written petition to the council setting forth the reasons for the appeal. The appeal shall be heard and determined within 60 days from its filing. A majority vote of the council shall overrule the planning commission. 
(c)  Widening, narrowing, extension, enlargement, vacation or change of use of streets or public areas shall likewise be submitted for approval, but paving, repair, reconstruction, improvement, drainage or similar work and normal service extensions of public utilities or public service corporations shall not require approval unless involving a change in location or extent of a street or public area. 
(d)  Any public area, facility or use as set forth in subsection (a) of this section which is identified within, but not the entire subject of, a submission under either the state law for subdivision or the state law for development, or both, may be deemed a feature already shown on the adopted comprehensive plan, and, therefore, excepted from the requirement for submittal to and approval by the planning commission or the council; provided, however, that the council has by ordinance or resolution defined standards governing the construction, establishment or authorization of such public area, facility or use or has approved it through acceptance of a proffer made pursuant to state law. 
(Code 1972, § 2-133) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-456; advertisement of plans, ordinances, etc., joint public hearings, written notice of certain amendments, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-431; plat of proposed subdivision and site plans to be submitted for approval, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-475; permitted provisions in subdivision ordinances, amendments, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-491(h). 
Sec. 54-70. - Promotion of public interest and understanding. 
    The planning commission shall promote public interest in and an understanding of the comprehensive plan and, to that end, may publish and distribute copies of the comprehensive plan or of any report and may employ such other means of publicity and education as it may determine. 
(Code 1972, § 2-134) 
Sec. 54-71. - Consultation with public officials, citizens and other organizations. 
    The planning commission shall consult and advise with public officials and agencies, public utility companies, civil, educational, professional and other organizations and with citizens with relation to the protecting or carrying out of the comprehensive plan. 
(Code 1972, § 2-135) 
Sec. 54-72. - Surveys and studies. 
    In the preparation of the comprehensive plan, the planning commission shall make careful and comprehensive surveys and studies of existing conditions and future growth. 
(Code 1972, § 2-136) 
Chapter 58 - SECONDHAND GOODS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 18; taxation, ch. 70; zoning, ch. 90. 
State Law reference- Local regulation of automobile graveyards and junkyards, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-28; municipal regulation of pawnshops and secondhand dealers, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-866; local limitations as to number of pawnshops, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4002; permit for trading in secondhand building fixtures, Code of Virginia, §§ 59.1-117, 59.1-118; report by dealer in junk or secondhand personal property to chief of police or sheriff, Code of Virginia, § 59.1-121; sale or exchange of secondhand watches, Code of Virginia, § 59.1-131 et seq. 

Sec. 58-1. - Junk and secondhand dealers; weekly reports. 
    Every purchaser of or dealer in secondhand articles or junk shall make a report to the chief of police on blanks to be furnished by him, covering transactions of the previous week, Monday through Saturday, on or before Wednesday of each week, showing a list or description of all secondhand articles bought, or on which money or other thing of value is loaned, and a description of the person from whom received, his name, place of residence and occupation. If there be no such property received, he shall report that fact, and the word "none" shall be sufficient for that purpose. 
(Code 1972, § 14-39) 
Chapter 62 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Department of public works, § 41 et seq. 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; buildings and building regulations, ch. 14; planning, ch. 54; subdivisions, ch. 66; traffic and vehicles, ch. 74; utilities, ch. 78; vegetation, ch. 82; vehicles for hire, ch. 86. 
State Law reference- Streets, alleys, sidewalks, etc., generally, Code of Virginia, §§ 15.1-14(1), (9), 15.1-363 et seq., 15.1-888 et seq.; limited access streets in cities and towns, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-16; bicycle trails or paths, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-16.2; official map, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-458 et seq.; local authority over highways, Code of Virginia, § 33.1-224 et seq.; pipelines and other works in streets, alleys, etc., Code of Virginia, § 56-257 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 62-1. - Drainage-From gutters of projecting eaves. 
    All buildings, the eaves of which project over the sidewalk, shall be provided with gutters so that there shall be no dripping from the eaves upon the sidewalk. All gutters, the waters from which empty upon a street or sidewalk, shall be so constructed as to discharge such water only at or below the surface of the ground. No building shall be constructed with eaves projecting over the sidewalk. 
(Code 1972, § 18-2) 
Sec. 62-2. - Same-Over footways; abatement. 
    No water from any lot, gutter or spout shall be permitted to flow across the footway of any street except in a covered drain, the cover of which shall not be above the surface of such footway. Such drain shall be of sufficient capacity to convey the water to be discharged by it, and shall be built and kept open and in good repair by the owner or occupant of the premises whence it proceeds. Any person violating this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-11 after notice by the city manager or superintendent of public works to abate the same; provided, however, that in case of failure to comply with the order to abate within five days, the city manager or superintendent of public works may cause the construction to be made at the cost of the city, and the cost thereof, with 20 percent additional as a fine, shall be collected from the party in default in like manner as fines and assessments are collected. 
(Code 1972, § 18-3) 
Sec. 62-3. - Fruit skins, vegetables, other dangerous items. 
    No person shall throw upon the sidewalks or streets any rind, skin or peeling of any fruit, vegetable or other article liable to cause any person to slip or fall, or endanger the public health. 
(Code 1972, § 18-5) 
Sec. 62-4. - Cleanliness-Duty of abutting occupant generally. 
    It shall be the duty of all persons occupying stores or premises fronting on any street to keep the sidewalk immediately in front thereof clean and clear of rubbish, trash, wastepaper, filth and other offensive matter, and they shall not sweep the same into a driveway or street, but shall take up the same and put it in proper receptacles to be removed as other trash, wastepaper, filth and other offensive matter is removed. During dry weather, sidewalks shall be sprinkled with water before sweeping so as to prevent dust from flying into faces of pedestrians. In case of office buildings, apartment houses or other buildings occupied by three or more tenants, this duty shall be upon the owner, or the person in charge of the entire building. Where the first floor is occupied as a store or mercantile establishment, the duty of keeping the sidewalk in front thereof clean shall be and is hereby imposed upon the occupant of such store or proprietor of the mercantile business. 
(Code 1972, § 18-7) 
Sec. 62-5. - Same-Sweeping from interior onto sidewalk. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sweep dirt or trash from the interior of a store or premises occupied by him upon the sidewalk, but such dirt or trash shall be taken up and put in proper receptacles for removal. 
(Code 1972, § 18-8) 
Sec. 62-6. - Same-Private alley. 
    It shall be the duty of every owner of a private alley to have the same so graded as to prevent the accumulation therein of water or filth, and keep the same constantly clean and in good order. Every 24 hours that he shall so neglect or refuse to comply with the provisions of this section, after notice of the violation by the city manager, superintendent of public works or chief of police, shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1972, § 18-9) 
Sec. 62-7. - Same-Throwing or depositing of glass and other injurious items; enumeration. 
(a)  No person shall throw or deposit upon any street or sidewalk any glass bottle, glass, nails, tacks, wire, cans or any other substance likely to injure any person, animal or vehicle upon such street or sidewalk; nor shall any person throw or deposit, or cause or allow to be deposited, upon any street or sidewalk any soil, sand, mud, gravel or other substance so as to create a hazard or nuisance to the public. 
(b)  Any person who drops, or permits to be dropped or thrown, upon any street or sidewalk any destructive or injurious material shall immediately remove the same or cause it to be removed. 
(c)  Any person removing a wrecked or damaged vehicle from a street shall remove any glass or other injurious substance dropped upon the street or sidewalk from such vehicle. 
(Code 1972, § 18-10) 
Cross reference- Traffic and vehicles, ch. 74. 
Sec. 62-8. - Removal of sand or earth. 
    No person shall remove sand or earth from the streets or sidewalks of the city. 
(Code 1972, § 18-12) 
Cross reference- Damaging property generally, § 50-303. 
Secs. 62-9-62-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - STREETS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 62-36. - Stopping travel on streets under repair. 
    The city shall have the right to stop travel on any street when the same is being repaved or improved, if deemed necessary. 
(Code 1972, § 18-6) 
Sec. 62-37. - Placement of poles of telegraph, electric or telephone companies. 
    Telegraph, electric and telephone companies, when authorized by the council to do business in the city, may place such reasonable number of poles in the streets as may be requisite for their business, but such poles shall be located and moved according to the direction and under the supervision of the city manager and superintendent of public works. No telephone, telegraph, electric or other pole shall be erected on the streets except immediately within and against the curbing of the sidewalks. Any such poles already erected outside the curbing shall be removed when so directed by the council. No such poles shall be erected until inspected and approved by the city manager or superintendent of public works. 
(Code 1972, § 18-11) 
State Law reference- Municipal franchises, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-307 et seq. 
Secs. 62-38-62-55. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ACCEPTANCE 

Sec. 62-56. - Minimum right-of-way and roadway widths. 
    Before any street will be accepted for maintenance and improvement, it must have an unrestricted right-of-way of 50 feet and have a roadway of not less than 30 feet graded, drained and graveled to the satisfaction of the council; provided, however, that the council may waive such requirements in previously recorded nonconforming subdivisions. 
(Code 1972, § 18-13) 
Sec. 62-57. - By ordinance or resolution. 
    The acceptance of any dedication of any street may be done only by ordinance or resolution especially adopted, according to law, for that purpose. 
(Code 1972, § 18-14) 
Sec. 62-58. - Prerequisite to improvement at public expense. 
    No street shall be deemed entitled to improvement at the public expense unless such street shall have been opened or legally recognized or accepted as such by the city, through the council. 
(Code 1972, § 18-15) 
Sec. 62-59. - Additional prerequisites. 
    No street or any extension of a street located in the city, which street is platted, designed, laid out or constructed primarily for the purpose of providing access to land abutting on such street, shall be opened, recognized or accepted by the city unless and until the following requirements as to the preparation of the street have been complied with: 
(1)  Grading, drainage, surfacing and surface treatment. Such street shall be graded, drained, surfaced and surface treated without expense to the city, and the street widths, alignment and grades, as well as the quality and quantity of materials and the quality of workmanship, shall be approved by the city. 
(2)  Width of streets. All such streets shall have a minimum width of 50 feet; provided, however, that on such streets being used as such, but which have not been accepted by the city which because of location of improvements and building on adjoining property, it is impossible to accept the street, the city may waive the 50-foot right-of-way, provided other improvements required in this section are made. 
(3)  Sanitary sewers. A sanitary sewer shall be installed in the street for the full length of the street and shall be connected with existing sewerage of the city before the street is surface treated, and the size, type, location and grade of such sewer shall be approved by the city. The cost of such installation shall be borne one-third by the city and two-thirds by the real estate developer or person offering to dedicate the street. 
(4)  Water main. A water main shall be installed in such street for the full length of the street and shall be connected with the existing water system of the city before the street is surface treated, and the size, type, location and grade of the water main shall be approved by the city. The cost of such installation shall be paid one-third by the city and two-thirds by the real estate developer or person offering to dedicate the street. 
(5)  Curb and gutter. If the person offering to dedicate such street agrees that a curb and gutter on such street will be mutually beneficial to the city and to the abutting property owners if installed, such curb and gutter may be installed; provided, however, that the city shall pay one-third of the cost of such curb and gutter and the person offering to dedicate the street shall pay two-thirds of the cost of such curb and gutter; and provided further that such curb and gutter shall be constructed according to the city's specifications, grades and alignment. 
(6)  Method of work; payment of costs. The city shall approve and let the contract for all such improvements, or do the work under its own supervision. Prior to acceptance by the city, the city manager shall prepare an estimate of the cost of the work and the person offering to dedicate the street shall deposit with the city two-thirds of the entire cost based on the estimate, together with a signed agreement that he will pay two-thirds of the cost and will deposit at any time on request by the city additional funds if the cost is more than the original estimate. The city will refund any deposit in excess of two-thirds of the cost. 
(7)  Refusal to aid in improvement. The city council may in its discretion refuse to appropriate city funds or assume the responsibility of making any contribution for the improvement of any street or development if such refusal is deemed for the best interests of the city. 
(Code 1972, § 18-16) 
Cross reference- Utilities, ch. 78; applications for sewer line extensions for commercial and industrial use, § 78-167. 
Sec. 62-60. - Sharing in improvements by city. 
    The city is in no way obligated to share in the cost of any improvements to water, sewer, curb, gutter, and like matters, and shall share in the cost of such improvements only when there are sufficient funds available and when there will be a direct benefit to the public as a whole. 
(Code 1972, § 18-17) 
Secs. 62-61-62-85. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SIDEWALKS 

Sec. 62-86. - Width. 
    No sidewalk, where space therefor is adequate, shall be less than five feet in width, including the width of the curb. 
(Code 1972, § 18-1) 
Sec. 62-87. - Snow, sleet and ice removal. 
    It shall be the duty of occupants of every house or lot which abuts upon a sidewalk or footway of concrete, stone, brick or wood, to have all snow removed from such sidewalk or footway within six hours after the snow shall have ceased falling, unless such snow shall have fallen during the night or on Sunday, in which case it shall be removed by 12:00 noon on the day following. The same requirements shall exist with respect to ice or sleet on sidewalks or footways, except that the same, when it cannot be removed without injury to the sidewalk or footway, shall be covered, within the period of time specified, with sand, ashes or some other substance which will render it safe for travel. Whenever any house or lot is unoccupied, it shall be the duty of the owner, or the agent of the owner thereof, to have the snow or ice removed from his sidewalk or footway, as required in this section of occupants. 
(Code 1972, § 18-4) 
Secs. 62-88-62-115. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - IMPROVEMENT ON REQUEST 

Sec. 62-116. - Authorized; required deposit. 
    Subject to section 62-117, when, on any street which has been accepted by the city and is a part of the city system, the owners of property adjoining such street request the paving of the street, the installation of curb and gutter or sidewalk, the council may in its discretion pave the street or install the curb and gutter or sidewalk, upon receipt of a written petition signed by the property owners agreeing to pay two-thirds of the cost of the installation of a curb and gutter or sidewalk. If the council approves such request, prior to the paving of the street or installation, an estimate of the cost of the work shall be made and the property owners shall deposit two-thirds of the amount of such estimate. Any deficiency between two-thirds of the actual cost and the two-thirds of the estimated cost shall be paid by the property owner, and any overpayment by the property owner shall be refunded. 
(Code 1972, § 18-18) 
Sec. 62-117. - Sufficiency of requests. 
    Paving of the street or installation of curb and gutter or sidewalk on any street which has been accepted by the city and is a part of the city system shall be made only in areas where there are sufficient requests, filed as provided in section 62-116, to award a contract, according to the discretion of the council. 
(Code 1972, § 18-19) 
Sec. 62-118. - Accomplishment of work. 
    When a street is to be paved or curb and gutter or sidewalk is to be installed pursuant to section 62-116, the city shall do the work or contract the work and shall have entire supervision and control of the project. 
(Code 1972, § 18-20) 
Sec. 62-119. - Payment of entire cost by city. 
    Nothing contained in this article shall be construed to prevent the city from the installation and payment of entire cost of curb and gutter or sidewalks, in areas where such improvements are deemed necessary for the benefit of the community. 
(Code 1972, § 18-21) 
Secs. 62-120-62-145. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - EXCAVATIONS 

Sec. 62-146. - Permit required. 
    No person, unless specially authorized by the council, shall take up or remove any portion of the surface of the sidewalk or street, or excavate therein without written permission of the city manager, who shall not refuse permission to any applicant except for cause. In case of refusal, the applicant may appeal to the council. 
(Code 1972, § 18-22) 
Sec. 62-147. - Deposits; acquiescence to article provisions. 
    Before a permit to remove a pavement or street surface or excavate therein is granted, the city manager may require a deposit sufficient to pay for resurfacing the street or sidewalk to be disturbed, the amount of such deposit to be determined by the city manager. Every person who shall make application shall be deemed to have assented thereby to all the provisions and terms of this article, including the right of the city to collect the actual cost of replacing the pavement, sidewalk or street surface in the manner directed in this section. 
(Code 1972, § 18-23) 
Sec. 62-148. - Duty to prosecute work without delay. 
    It shall be the duty of every person to whom a permit to remove a pavement or street surface or excavate therein shall have been granted, to institute at once and prosecute without delay the work for which such permit was obtained, and promptly, on its completion, to give written notice to the city manager. 
(Code 1972, § 18-24) 
Sec. 62-149. - Supervision of work; replacing surface. 
    No pavement, sidewalk or street surface shall be replaced, after being taken up, by any person except under the direction of the city manager. If the applicant fails to resurface the street disturbed promptly and in a manner approved by the city manager, the city manager is authorized to cause such work to be done at the expense of the applicant. 
(Code 1972, § 18-25) 
Sec. 62-150. - Guarding by lights and barriers; responsibility for damages. 
    Any person to whom a permit is granted under section 62-146 shall place guards or barriers around the work or excavation in question and shall protect it by warning lights at night, and shall be responsible for damages to persons or property caused by such work or excavations until taken in charge by the city manager. Any person failing to place such guards, barriers or lights as required by this section shall, in addition, be punished as provided in section 1-11. 
(Code 1972, § 18-26) 
Sec. 62-151. - Work done by city forces. 
    The provisions of section 62-150 shall not apply to work done by city forces under the supervision of the city manager, but the city manager may prescribe regulations for work done on city streets by city forces. 
(Code 1972, § 18-27) 
Secs. 62-152-62-175. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - OBSTRUCTIONS 

Sec. 62-176. - General prohibition. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct the sidewalks or streets of the city. This shall not be construed to prevent merchants from displaying their goods in front of their stores in a reasonable manner. 
(Code 1972, § 18-43) 
Sec. 62-177. - Awnings, signs, or other fixtures; blocking street or sidewalk; height. 
    No awning, sign or other fixture shall be erected or constructed in such a way as to impede or obstruct the streets or sidewalks. In no case shall any awning, overhanging sign or fixture be allowed or constructed less than seven feet over the sidewalks or less than 20 feet above the streets. 
(Code 1972, § 18-44) 
Sec. 62-178. - Building operation; lighting; restoration; shed over sidewalk. 
    The permit to erect any building or structure shall carry with it the privilege of obstructing the adjacent sidewalk and a portion of the street for a reasonable time, if necessary, with the material for building, but this privilege shall not carry with it the right to obstruct the sidewalk and portion of street any longer than the obstruction is absolutely necessary, and no more thereof than necessary, and at no time shall more than one-fourth of the street and one-half of the sidewalk be obstructed. It shall be the duty of the owner to place on such obstructions every night one or more lights as necessity demands as a warning to the people.
